title: League is just "who can be a meta-slave"
body:
After playing a few games where my friends and I went off-meta (troll) builds I had a realisation that League isn't how it used to be. People no longer play this game for fun, they play it to win and feed their e-ego. 

Have we lost sight of what video games should be played for, being the fun aspect? Is gaming literally just "who can win" now?

replies.body:
I have a sneaking suspicion that if we just turned off our API for like...2 months we'd start to see a lot more creativity and "off meta" decisions being made again. As a competitive sport/game depending on your degree of investment in league, it's only natural that people will attempt to optimize the game as much as possible to give them the best chance to win. That gets made all that much easier when you can go to any 3rd party sight and look at whatever is "the strongest" champ/build order/strat on any given patch. Then throw the LCS into the equation and you not only have numbers to look at, but demonstrations by the best players in the game in how to play the game best. 

I was personally finding myself get a bit burnt out in ranked this season, so started focusing more on normals with friends and just tried out champs I haven't played in ages, or took them in weird spots (Brand jungle). Even though I'm sure it's far from optimal, it was actually super fun to just try funky shit again. That was one thing I loved seeing when we first rolled out runes reforged (or the rune builder website). I was seeing so many people going "oh shit! These specific runes on this champ sound so fun I can't wait to try it!". You know, true theorycrafting, something of a lost art over the years. What we were seeing was players reading tooltips and getting excited envisioning moments in game, not looking at and trying to crunch the numbers for what was best. There was excitement, there was creativity, there was fun. Then runes launched and people immediately turned to 3rd party websites to figure out what the optimal pages were, and we saw decision making quickly converge on what the numbers said, not on what sounded fun. Part of it is we don't yet have the system to the point where you have to think hard about what's optimal, and part of it is human nature. Losing feels bad. So you tend to optimize to chase the win, as opposed to take the risk of picking something "troll" and lose a game/waste your time. 

This is hardly scratching the surface, but it's something i've been lamenting on weekends, and something I don't have a good answer to.

I think riot needs to actively encourage and support this kind of behavior more. Not just with balance changes but actively trying to foster a different attitude in players.

The reason for this is simply...League, by nature and design, simply does not provide a fun enough game for a player to feel as if they can afford the loss as everything inbetween either of the Nexuses exploding is not worth the frustration that stems for losing.

Simply put, League is just not that fun. It's far too punishing to the player as in this game, almost all players know that a SECOND is a LONG time. It can cost a lot to just "have fun" and screw around with your friends, using emotes, allowing animations to finish on emotes. Interacting with taunts. It takes time, time the enemy will make you pay for.

And as soon as the opponent gets ahead, the game will close out fast. And i meant REAL FAST. It can take about 5 to 10 minutes to finish a game after you're getting legitimately stomped on from trying to have fun and not care about winning. The enemies can literally take away all of your attempts at succeeding to have fun, whatever that may be, and disable you from playing the game by killing you through stomping you that you allowed to happen as you were trying to have fun.

It's why games like PUBG or CoD are popular for example. People don't really care for winning as much as they care for playing everything inbetween the end of the game screen.

Kind-of sad, but it puts the competitivness of League in perspective.

My favorite off-meta picks got explicitly changed to not be able to go in those roles anymore. Riot didn't want Kog'Maw mid, Zac top was fun, but his unnecessary rework didn't even consider him as a toplaner. Skarner's and Mordekaiser reworks also came with changes that almost prevented them from going toplane.

Players make champion picks based on Riot's API, but it doesn't help that Riot makes balancing decisions that force champions into certain roles.

My post got downvoted to oblivion, but the important part is, I 100% agree with this.

Between the realities of matchmade queues and the amount of people you need to play League, the attitude of ranked, game length, and a bunch of other factors (like the gradual streamlining of the item system that you mention and the removal of weird or niche items like Sword of the Divine), League is just really, really bad for Johnny-type players. It's hard for them to find satisfaction. And the game is being pushed further away from it in the name of removing noobtraps and streamlining the game -- which is an understandable design goal if you assume the entire playerbase is very Spike-y, but it is leaving some older players out to dry.

I'm very Spike-y myself, so I don't mind it as much (and from a balance perspective, Johnny is very demanding) -- but I admit there's still a part of me that enjoyed doing things like playing Triforce Sona ADC in S3 and trying to steamroll the game as fast as possible before I fell off , and that'd still be nice to indulge every once in a while.

For everybody else burnt on WIN WIN  WIN AAARRRGGG TILLLLT attitudes. Grab homies, play with friends, or recruit random strangers who just wanna have fun. Custom games may work, better off recruiting folks in advanced.

I remember in S0 (before ranked was made) every champion used to have ap decent'ish ratios in their kits. Now? It hardly scales even if you had 1000AP.

---

Then we have your (as in: Riot HQ) boner for ADC. How can we not use ADCs if they outperform almost everyone else with a huge gap? You guys are enforcing the ADC META just like a pimp protect his..uh... mobile docking stations..

---

Edit: Players are also ones to blame, cause we all want to win and want to do it most efficiently, but if you'd remove the vast gaps between certain classes [EKHM] ADC and everyone else [EKHM] and maybe buff certain ability ratios on few champs, then we might actually see some reasonably well performing off-meta builds like... AP GP? Or.. AP Jinx? Or.. AP Cait.. Oh wait, her AP build was gutted with her rework.

+ RIOT wont want to buff weak champion because that will break low elo game. (was written in  developer blog)
+ RIOT made a meta, not players ( lane swap tactics was removed, non-jungler cant jungler any more)

Here is the first thought I came to: Make an "Off-Meta" Queue.  In the other three SR Normal queues, people EXPECT you to play to win.  If there were a queue that was very specifically an "I'm here to goof off and have fun" queue, the expectation of winning or losing goes away.  It'd be like the "Memes & Games" of the actual game.  You go there to be ridiculous and have a good time, win or lose.

Edit: As another thought, this could be the queue that also lifts one or two limitations other queues have, like allowing multiple people to pick the same champ.  People could make their own "All for One" on one side (and potentially lose horribly), but who DOESN'T want to know if an all Jhin team could take out a meta team?

Ok, let me put it this way. If I play Quinn bot lane into a Tristana I will almost definitely lose because Tristana is just that good. It doesn't matter if she's bronze or challenger, I will lose no matter what because that pick is just broken. 
Or better example, I pick Riven into Maokai. Even if he's bad I likely cannot kill him, yet he can kill me due to how good his base damages are and how much CC he has. Even if I roam to other lanes I'm still at a disadvantage because he beats me in roams. My skill as a Riven is almost completely negated when someone picks a meta tank top laner.

My skill level can only interact so much with what I pick. I could make pretty much everything work before season 8 (and the preseason), so what's holding me back now? 

I've been looking to better myself at this game for 8 years, got d2 at one point too. But like....my skill doesn't matter against picks that are just braindead auto-win. Case and point, Malzahar. Actually, this is less a champion specific problem, this is a general game problem. There's too much (mind my french) bullshit in this game and the game is sooo team focused that my own skill level hardly affects the outcome of the game. 
But again, that wasn't my main point. My main point was that this game is less about fun and more about winning to most players. That is a glaring flaw to this game since "fun" is what drives players to recruit more players, play more of the game and really cherish their time playing this game. No one cherishes a game where the only purpose of it is to win.

"But people get enjoyment out of winning!" you may cry. That is true, but would you really call that having fun? Is personal satisfaction really the best outcome in gaming? I'd argue that general fun and a sense of belonging in a group/community would bring more enjoyment to people's experiences if they could just get past the whole "I NEED TO WIN THIS" mentality. 
Sure, winning is an objective, but it should never be the primary focus in video games. Hence why games like Halo Combat Evolved still live on in people's hearts, because it struck the perfect balance between having fun and the intense desire to win.
